Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Formation, properties and evolution of protoplanetary vortices: Multiscale investigations of baroclinic instability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Protoplanetary disks (PPDs) are geometrically thin, rotating sheets of gas and dust that surround young stars, and are thought to be the birthplace of planets such as our own. Fluid instabilities and turbulence within the disk gas are thought to be the primary mechanisms for concentrating solid particles and initiating the planet building process, yet it is not known currently which instability or combination thereof is responsible. Computational constraints limit numerical simulations of PPDs to resolutions that are incapable of resolving all temporal and spatial scales of dynamical relevance. The PIs are overcoming these limitations by developing a multi-scale mathematical model for the purpose of identifying and simulating fluid instabilities and turbulence in PPDs. In this respect, the proposed work can be viewed as a new computational and modeling framework that will potentially allow for the highest resolution simulations of PPD dynamics to date. Particular emphasis is being placed on understanding the nonlinear properties, through the use of high resolution numerical simulations, of the new Equatorial Vortex Instability (EVI) that has been identified by the PIs. By employing rigorous asymptotic methods, a hierarchical set of equations that is capable of simultaneously modeling small-scale and global-scale dynamics and the coupling between the two scales is under development for the first time. The results of the proposed investigation will provide a more comprehensive understanding of (1) the effi_ciency and interplay between various instability mechanisms, (2) the interaction between global and local instabilities, and (3) a better understanding of the role of turbulent vortices in enhancing the formation of planetesimals through the segregation and agglomeration of small particles.

Protoplanetary disks (PPDs) are rotating sheets of gas and dust that surround young stars, and are thought to be the birthplace of planets such as our own. Fluid motions within the disk gas are thought to be the primary mechanism for concentrating solid material and initiating the planet building process, yet it is not known currently how such motions originate. Computer simulations have proven to be valuable tools for advancing our understanding of PPD dynamics. However, it is not currently possible to capture all the temporal and spatial scales of dynamical relevance in PPDs given modern-day technological constraints. The PIs are overcoming these limitations by developing the first multi-scale mathematical model for the purpose of identifying and simulating fluid motion in PPDs. In this respect, the proposed work can be viewed as a new computational and modeling framework that will allow for the highest resolution simulations of PPD dynamics to date.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project engaged in multiscale asymptotic investigations of fluid instabilities occurring with protoplanetary disks. A long standing and unresolved problem in planetary accretion disks is the creation and saturation of turbulent fluid motions that promote formation of planetary embryos within the relevant window of time prior to the central younf star reaching main sequence. The scales involved in the fluid instability are disparate and beyond the scope of brute force direct numerical simulations (DNS). 

In this project, we derived and investigated several reduced asymptotic models. They can be divided into two classes - magnetic (turbulence is generated by the magnetorotational instability)  and hydrodynamic (where turbulence is driven baroclinicly. As an executive statement, all reduced models produced in this proposal effort were rigorously derived from the master equations and provide a new foundation for future modeling efforts (much beyond the numerical investigations explored). 

Magnetorotational Instability: We demonstrated for the first time in a regime of astrophysical relevance that the instability can be saturated by a strong feedback mechanism on the magnetic field permeating the disk. Notably, saturation does not require an adjustment of the primary Keplerian balance between the gravitional force on the disk by the central star and the centrifugal force of the disk. The Kleperian balance is known to be dominant and attempt by the PI's prior to this project required a certain degree of its relaxation. The work has been published in a peer reviewed Journal and disseminated at leading conferences and workshops. 

Baroclinic Instability: Several asymptotic models were derived and explored numerically. All cases resulted in peer reviewed publicaitons and dissemination at leading conferences and workshops. 

(i) Shear driven turbulence is a component part of accretion disks. The equations studied are derived by an asymptotically consistent procedure valid for large Reynolds numbers and allow the computation of exact coherent structures in such flows. A numerical procedure for obtaining these structures was developed and implemented.

(ii) Fluids within disks can often be viewed as multicomponent and if the components possess differing diffusive properties it is known that double-diffusive instabilities arise. This project derived and investigated two new models  for what is known as the fingering instability. The models were shown to capture prior results from direct numerical simulations. Yet they go further, reaching parameter regimes beyond the scope of direct numerical simulations. The models were able to clarify the nature and relevance of saturation mechanisms reported in the science literature. Investigations also revealed the formation of jets with both steady and temporal variability. 

(iii) Equatorial convection. This work focused on convection about the equatorial plane where gravity and rotation are perpendicular to one another. The reduced model was verified by a detailed quantitative analysis with the full equations through DNS. Notably, this effort required the development of a newalgorithm that handles an unbounded direction with spectral accuracy with the use of rational Chebyshev polynomials. Specifically, this work was published in a leading computatinal journal.

Finally, we note that the simulations of mutlscale asymptotic models still require the development of new algorithms, especially model approximations of the fine-scale dynamics. The PI continue to pursue these issues which have included additional proposal effors.
